6:10-6:16 Actually English is like that when compared to German.  I can't 
recall enough German to give an example but I know that the subject word is 
spelled differently based on context, so it uses is less conjunctive words 
and more word variations.  However there are some big'ass words in German 
which have simple but specific meanings.  Lastly both German and Spanish 
are sexed language so they have more words describing masculine and 
feminine, like das(das), die(D), der(deer) all mean "the" in German; if I 
remember correctly der is masculine, die is feminine, das is neural. Here's 
a simple example: Der mann trinkst wasser. Translated is: The man is 
drinking water.  As you might have noticed there's no "ing" in German; so a 
German speaking person, speaking in english would likely say: The man 
drinks water.  So to finish my point, German is usually more specific per 
syllable then English. ﻿

Gun-owning American here.  That answer was kind of lacking IMO.  It's not 
about power.  I would say that is the least of the reasons.

One, America could not have happened without firearms.  Fighting the 
natives (horrible as it was), fighting the British (they had it coming 
though ;) ), hunting- early Americans *needed* guns.  If you didn't have a 
gun you were dependent on someone else for your food and your protection. 
 Americans like freedom. We do not like to be beholden to anyone else for 
any reason, so that independence guns provided our ancestors has persisted 
in a feeling of independence today- even though we rarely hunt or need to 
defend ourselves. 

Two, the guys who founded America, the Founding Fathers I think they are 
called, were not big fans of totalitarian regimes.  They really did want 
citizens to have a last ditch recourse against another King George III 
wanna be if it came to that.  That also persist today - this country was 
founded by people who did not trust government, so what do you expect?  I 
have to disagree with the suggestion that private firearm ownership is not 
a deterrent to government overreach too- because militias showed up, armed 
to the teeth, and Cliven Bundy still has his cows on Federal land, now 
doesn't he?  Why didn't the government just take them out? Because that 
would have just made things worse.  The threat of things getting out of 
hand was great enough that the government backed down (even though Bundy 
was clearly in the wrong).

I agree with the language thing, too.  We don't because we don't really 
have to.  We're waaaay over here away from almost anyone else, most 
immigrants learn English within a generation or two, and the people most 
Americans meet even in Mexico (tourism industry employees) speak English 
anyway.

About the cars question.  We didn't invent the automobile (Vielen Danke, 
Herr Benz) but we sure took the idea and ran with it. It may be in shambles 
now, but once upon a time Detroit really was the car capitol of the world. 
  Plus, America is freaking HUGE.  The distance between Copenhagen and 
Vienna would not even get you out of my home state!  Everything is spread 
out here- to the point that mass transit is only viable in larger cities 
and in those few areas that are heavily developed, like New England and 
parts of California and Florida.  So most Americans don't just want cars- 
we need them just to get around.  For example, even when traffic is light 
you can't get from the south end of Houston to the north end in under 30 
minutes- and that is on the freeway going 65 MPH!  Oh, and remember that 
freedom thing? yeah, that's another reason we like cars: the freedom to go 
anywhere we want anytime we want, no schedules, baggage checks, or tickets 
required.﻿

Guns have always been part of the American culture. Monarchies don’t like 
an armed peasantry. It wouldn’t do if every time the king issued a 
proclamation someone started an armed revolt. It wouldn’t be good to be the 
king if the peasants had guns.
When the Americas were colonies, the British colonies were being settled by 
peoples who were poor for the most part. The civilized people were in 
Albany or Boston or Philadelphia they didn’t have to go any further for 
their daily bread. The poor people who immigrated to the colonies had to 
move to the frontier to have any chance. They wanted to own land and wanted 
to be left alone to live their lives as they saw fit. The British Army 
wasn’t on the frontier (except when the French and Indians became a 
problem). So the people on the frontier were left to their own devices and 
HAD to have a firearm.
Why? Because on the frontier there was nothing but a vast wilderness filled 
with deprivations and threats of all kinds.  If you wanted to eat you 
hunted. If an animal attacked you, you could defend yourself. If Indians 
threatened you could fight them off. If you needed money or clothing, you 
could hunt for skins. A firearm has been necessary for Americans to live, 
survive and eat from the 1600’s right into the twentieth century. Why are 
Americans obsessed about our firearms? Because we ALWAYS have been. This 
would be difficult for Europeans to understand because they have never 
needed firearms.
If their governments needed their subjects to bear arms they were issued 
guns and sent off to war. During the American Revolution many American 
soldiers showed up with their own guns. This leads to the other great 
American tradition. To be left the hell alone to live our lives as we see 
fit.﻿

Americans are smart (well some are) I am 11 years old I am in advanced math 
in the 6 grade here is a question that was on my homework

My grandson is about as many days as my son in weeks, and my grandson is as 
many months as I am in years. My grandson, my son and I together are 120 
years. Can you tell me my age in years ? 

     Answer & Explanation
Solution:
I am 72 years old.

Let m be my age in years. If s is my son's age in years, then my son is 52s 
weeks old. If g is my grandson's age in years, then my grandson is 365g 
days old. Thus,
365g = 52s.
Since my grandson is 12g months old,
12g = m.
Since my grandson, my son and I together are 120 years,
g + s + m = 120.
The above system of 3 equations in 3 unknowns (g, s and m) can be solved as 
follows.
m / 12 + 365 m / (52 x 12) + m = 120 or
52 m + 365 m + 624 m = 624 x 120 or
m = 624 x 120 / 1041 = 72.
So, I am 72 years old.M 11﻿

I think the lack of motivation to learn another language has a lot to do 
with the general timing at which the opportunity is introduced. In several 
other countries, students start learning another language early in life; at 
elementary and middle school levels. I've even heard of foreign schools 
conducting half of an average school day in one language and devoting the 
other half in another; this being for young children. I was first 
introduced to another language (Spanish) in Highschool through required 
classes for graduation. I started off excited and eager to learn. But by 
then, my work load was extreme and I juggled my attention between multiple 
subjects. Adding another language to the mix didn't help and my desire 
slowly.. died. My original plan of taking four years of Spanish and 
continuing in collage quickly changed to two years (the minimum required) 
and moving on with my life. I've had no desire to continue ever since. I 
feel this case is similar in a lot American families who have no bi-lingual 
background, such as my own, and otherwise. Maybe if more American schools 
introduced foreign languages into the curriculum earlier on where 
situations aren't as intense, the circumstance would be different. ﻿

Two things here:

1) I think the argument that the Second was only meant to apply to militia 
members lacks all historical perspective.  At the time the United States 
was founded, about 90% of the population was rural settlers.  These people 
relied on firearms for subsistence hunting- not everyone raised livestock 
enough to butcher, and even if a market was less that a few days travel 
away, most settlers were too poor to buy a side of beef or something.  So 
they hunted.  Firearms were a common tool then.  Why would the Founding 
Fathers put such a constraint on what was an everyday necessity for 
survival? They wouldn't- it was a commonsense assumption that people should 
have the ability to own a basic means of survival.  The militia clause of 
the Second was just that- a legal means to organize militias before the 
U.S. had a standing army.

2) regardless of what the Founding Fathers intended, since Heller vs DC and 
McDonald vs Chicago, what they intended doesn't matter.  It's pretty 
obvious that you're not American, so I don't expect you to know how our 
government works.  But I am going to explain it.

As you may know, pretty much everything in U.S. law depends on the 
Constitution.  Our SCOTUS (Supreme Court of the United States) is the last 
word on determining if a law is Constitutional or not- they ultimately 
decide this by simple majority decision, and their word is final unless the 
Constitution itself is amended (this has happened only 17 times in the last 
224 years).  In 2008, SCOTUS decided by a narrow 5-4 margin that the Second 
Amendment applies to individual firearm ownership (DC vs Heller).  In 2010, 
in McDonald vs Chicago, SCOTUS decided that the Second applies at a Federal 
level (that is, all states must abide by it).  In short, all this means 
that no matter what one's opinion is, Americans have the Constitutional 
right to individually own firearms. Period, end of story, if you don't like 
it GTFO.

What SCOTUS did not say was that this precluded any forms of gun 
regulation.  There is still room for the Federal or even state governments 
to regulate what kinds fo firearms can be owned, but the ownership itself 
will never go away short of repealing the Second (good luck with that).

A few years ago, I damaged the tendon in my finger playing basketball.  I 
had recently lost my insurance, and couldn't afford surgery.

In order to mitigate the damage, there was a special brace I could buy that 
would hold my finger in the proper position to help the tendon heal.  It 
cost $800.  That wasn't including any charge for the doctor, that was just 
the price for the brace.  My doctor suggested the brace because I couldn't 
afford surgery.

I went online and found the brace and ordered it from the United Kingdoms 
for £15, including shipping, which is the equivalent of about $30.  $20 of 
that was shipping costs for shipping the thing clear from England.

My doctor confirmed that it was the exact same brace, and expressed his 
dismay at the state of the U.S. medical industry that had tried to scam me 
for $800 on a simple piece of metal and styrofoam that obviously shouldn't 
have cost anywhere near that much.

A few years before that, my daughter spent a night in the hospital, and 
when I looked at the bill, I noticed that they charged us $100 for each box 
of tissue that was opened while we were there.  It didn't affect me, 
because my insurance company picked up the check.  This was when I realized 
there was a problem with the insurance industry.  It wasn't until years 
later during a college research assignment that I fully realized why things 
worked this way.

Simple metal braces that could be ordered from Europe, and tissue paper are 
not new emerging medical technologies only available in the US.  Your 
hypothesis fails to explain why our medical industry was overcharging me in 
both instances by factors of 80 to 100 times the actual, reasonable price 
of simple goods.

As far as the metric system's non-existence in the US, it is a complete 
myth. Most if not all scientific sectors use the metric system exclusively. 
As far as machine shops, etc., systems of measurement are irrelevant for 
the most part. Parts are manufactured to conform to SI standards every day. 
US standards for industrial stock is probably the biggest hurdle, but its 
relevance is nearly inconsequential. The only thing that has prevented the 
US from moving away from the English system in the areas where it still 
exists is simply lack of necessity, and necessity is only driven by the 
bottom line.

We don't own guns for power. Is that why owning a gun was put into the bill 
of rights? No! We believe in the right to defend ourselves, especially 
during a time when we were at war with people who wanted to take away our 
liberties. Being able to protect your wellbeing is not equivalent to power. 
I am not a gun owner but I understand why guns mean so much to Americans. ﻿

First of all, one of the main reasons we have guns is because it's in 
our constitution. We have a right to bear arms. I know many people who own 
guns, but I do not know not one person who always has that gun with them. 
You either keep the gun at home, or you take it with your while hunting. We 
also have guns because we're scared. If someone breaks in, you'll be dead 
before you call 911. If you're in your own house and someone breaks in, you 
have the right to shoot them as self defense. It's not about power or 
seeming cool. 

     Secondly, about the whole sex thing. They were right for the most 
part. In school, there's always school assemblies or you might take a 
health class and learn about STI's. We have so many talks in school about 
the negatives of sex, that the kids actually start to get scared that 
something is going to happen to them. On top of that, America was formed by 
many puritans and still today most of the population is christian, so we 
learn in our teen years that the bible says we shouldn't have sex until 
married. 
     
     Third, many americans actually do know a second language and sometimes 
even a third. Either their parents teach it to them from a young age 
because of their roots, and/or you might take 2 years of a certain language 
in high school as in most schools, it's a requirement to graduate. Also, we 
don't really feel the need to because many don't even travel out of the 
country. Want to go somewhere hot? Hit up Florida or the southern states. 
There's plenty of vacation areas like ski resorts all over the country. We 
can experience everything in comfort of our own country. I live in Ohio. I 
can easily take an 8 hour drive to New York City if I'm really in the mood. 
I can take a road trip down to North Carolina and go to the beaches down 
there. I don't need to go to a completely different country and spend all 
that money to get there. Just a simple map and gas will get me where I 
need. 

     Fourth, as for the cars. It's more of a social class thing. If you 
have a nice car, it's a way of showing off. Plus, what they said is true. 
The US is a huge place. Like I said in the last paragraph, we could take a 
simple road trip to wherever we want. Saying that, we need a way to get 
there. The only place you will find taxis and buses is in the city. The 
suburbs and rural areas need cars to get everywhere. Just to get from my 
city to the next will take you at least 20-30 minutes. We also like the 
freedom cars give us. We can go wherever, whenever. No need to wait on 
anyone else. You don't need to wait at a place and leave at a certain time. 
In your own car, you get to choose that.

     Lastly, most americans don't think America is the best. We are proud 
of our country, but only the naive people are blind to the political 
problems going on. I know where I'm from, we like to take pride in things 
and show that. We love to host barbecues for the Fourth of July and go full 
out in red, white, and blue. We go all out in sports colors for the Super 
Bowl. To us, it's fun. We enjoy taking pride in who we are. It's just 
something we do. I guess you could say showing your pride is like an 
unwritten rule in America. It's seen as a good thing. We like to get 
together with our neighbors and celebrate our country. Almost everyone 
knows that we have many flaws, but so do other countries. Other countries 
probably believe their country is the best too. We take pride in our 
country, but we don't think it's the best. Many realize that we have a lot 
of things we can work on, but we also like to take a step back and just 
smile at how far we've gotten. Although we have many problems, we also like 
to look at the bright side of things. Another thing? We also exaggerate a 
lot, but who doesn't? A lot of times when we say something is the best, we 
don't really mean it. I get that we might be a little too proud sometimes, 
but don't think all of us are ignorant and naive to the problems going on. 
We see them, we really do. We also see the good things though, and that's 
something many people around the world fail to realize: there are good 
things about the United States of America too.﻿

+waterdamnaged So what is the problem with wanting the 2nd amendment to be 
taken out of the constitution?

+waterdamnaged It's interesting that you acknowledge this while 
simultaneously talking about the second amendment in the Bill of Rights as 
though it were holy and inviolate, perfectly written by the founding 
fathers to be maintained for all of eternity. Incidentally, in reading your 
earlier comments, I'd like to point out that you didn't quite get the 
wording of the amendment right. The sentence is, in fact, grammatically 
incorrect due to its first comma. That one article of punctuation has been 
responsible for more bitter disputes than any other I can think of: 
"A well regulated Militia, being necessary to the security of a free State, 
the right of the people to keep and bear Arms shall not be infringed." 


It appears clear that this amendment states that in order to defend a state 
from its enemies, *both foreign and domestic,* a militia is needed. And 
obviously this militia would be pretty ineffective without arms. 
Considering the historical context, I think it's safe to say that the 
framers were worried both about invasion from outside forces (England to 
the North and overseas, France to the West, Spain to the South) and about 
the degradation of the government into tyranny. A representative democracy 
was, after all, a giant experiment; nobody was sure it would work. 


All of that aside, I think it's important to *remain* with historical 
context long enough to acknowledge the fact that the firearms of the time 
were laughably slow, inaccurate, and generally unwieldy in comparison with 
the sleek killing machines of today. In those times, it would have been 
almost impossible for a child to shoot himself, even with a weapon that had 
just been loaded with powder and projectile. The possibility of someone 
firing more than a shot a second without reloading would have left the 
people of the day slack-jawed in shock.


The truth of the matter is that we've been beyond a second amendment world 
for a very, *very* long time; we just haven't acknowledged it. The way the 
amendment is currently worded, I find it difficult to imagine anybody 
allowing *any* restrictions on weapons. But I also know that nobody, 
probably not even a libertarian, would argue for a citizen's right to own 
and operate an armed tank or a rocket launcher. The second amendment is 
already being applied selectively; I think it's time we acknowledged that 
and drafted a new version appropriate to the times. 


Unfortunately, that will never happen as long as half the country deifies 
the founders and regards the Constitution as a holy document akin to the 
Bible.

+Walter Sobchak yes, and the US Constitution is no different in that 
regard. In fact, it has two different methods of amending it: Congressional 
(Parliamentary) and Convention. Essentially, the Constitution has changed 
every time it was amended and it's been done 27 times. If an amendment 
contradicts with what was established before in the Constitution, then the 
earlier language is automatically stricken out and disregarded ... even 
earlier amendments. It's this sole reason why it has endured for 225 years.

+waterdamnaged Has it occurred to you that in most nations the parliament 
can change the constitution and that discussing the constitution is part of 
democracy in most nations?

Contrary to popular beliefs, building a massive nationwide public 
transportation network in the U.S. would be a waste of time and money. 
Again, the country is HUGE and there are a whole lot of NOTHING in between 
the major cities. At most I can see a north/south transit system connecting 
the major cities at the eastern seaboard, as well a one on the west coast, 
and maybe a texas triangle. because the country is so huge, these smaller 
system would be basically the same size and just as efficient as their 
European or Japanese counterparts. But a giant hub all over the country 
would be pointless because by the time you hit the 500 mile mark you might 
as well fly. Plus what we have now isn't really all that different from 
other 1st world public transport in the city level. It's still inferior due 
to things like buses arriving every 30min instead of 15 but its layout and 
routes are pretty efficient and convenient and so are the trains like the 
Chicago or the New York subway systems. .﻿

+Julia Hoepffner I did. But my point is that the people of the United 
States are fully within their rights to call themselves "American." You're 
argument that they should be constrained because of "respect" is flawed for 
several reasons. For one, these other countries have their own identity 
that is separate from the American continent, similar to how Japan and 
China have their own separate identities that is distinct from the 
engulfing term "Asian." That is evidenced by the fact that the USA is the 
only country with the term "America" in its name. Why didn't the other 
countries in either North or South America do the same? Why isn't Brazil 
officially named "the Brazilian States of America"? Secondly, speaking in 
communal terms, these countries ARE CALLED American: Inter-American, 
Pan-American, North/South/Central American, or just plain American. That is 
reflected in several treaties and organizations comprising American 
countries as well as colloquial usage (if you say "Central America" or 
"Latin America," people know what you're talking about).

If this was such an issue, the governments of the other American countries 
would actually object. But they haven't. Because nobody really cares. So, 
stop trying to impose this name you've invented on U.S. citizens because 
you are flagrantly disrespecting the manner in which a nation of people 
have defined themselves for centuries: a right that has actually 
materialized as opposed to this hypothetical "right" of other North and 
South American countries to call themselves "American" when they have shown 
no interest whatsoever in actually claiming that name.

Many Americans (don't know exact number, but in the millions) have never 
even seen a gun in real life before (maybe if they see a police officer 
with one), let alone shot one even after seeing one. Many Americans who 
lean toward 'the left' in political ideology are feared by the media (also 
mainly left-leaning), so they're more than likely not willing to ever go 
see what it's like to shoot a gun. This is the imbalance of power we see 
today in the US and usually how many mass shooters get away with killing a 
lot of people *who choose not to arm themselves!*

Anyway, when I first shot a gun, I did not feel "powerful" or "unstoppable" 
at all, personally. I respected the gun as a powerful tool and just wanted 
to see how accurate my first shots were at the range. I was paying way more 
attention to handling the gun safely: *finger off trigger until aimed at 
target I'm willing to shoot*, keeping the gun pointed down range *at all 
times*; treating the gun as if it's loaded at all times, and etc.

It all depends on the individual, I guess. Many get excited after shooting 
guns, as I saw in another YouTube video of left-leaning people going to the 
gun range for the first time, but I did not get excited like a child at all 
my first time. :)
